intro: Scleria pygmaeopsis, commonly known as the dwarf bulrush, is a small, herbaceous plant native to southern Africa. It belongs to the Cyperaceae family, which includes sedges and related plants. The plant typically grows in wetland environments, such as marshes and along the edges of lakes and rivers. Its flowering stems are short and often bear small, spike-like inflorescences. Scleria pygmaeopsis is characterized by its narrow, grass-like leaves and its ability to thrive in waterlogged soils.
